SUMMARY: 2-Keto-3-deoxygluconate repressor, KdgR, is a DNA-binding transcription factor that represses transcription of operons involved in transport and catabolism of 2-keto-3-deoxy gluconate (KDG) [15659677, 4359651, 4571523, 4625742]. Synsis of se genes is induced when E. coli is grown in presence of KDG and under high-temperature conditions, between 32 and 35Â°C. Although little is known about regulating mechanism of KdgR, it has been shown to act as a repressor that binds to a putative inverted repeat sequence [11115104, 8107132]. Comparative analysis of intergenic DNA sequences showed consistent occurrence of KdgR possible binding sites upstream of genes not related to transport and catabolism of KDG [11115104, 15528647].
